awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Untangling the Complex Role of Anthropocentric Thinking in Undergraduate Biology Education
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to serve the national interest by improving undergraduate biology education.  It will do so by conducting basic research on how the intuitive thinking of biology students helps and/or hinders their learning of biological concepts in STEM learning environments. The project focuses on anthropocentric thinking, a particular kind of intuitive thinking that anchors understanding of the biological world in human terms. Anthropocentric thinking results in a tendency to see humans as biologically exceptional or to reason about other organisms by analogy to humans. Previous NSF-sponsored findings show that anthropocentric thinking may have a complex role in how undergraduates learn biological science. This project intends to examine this issue from three perspectives:  1) How students from different backgrounds may vary in the degree to which they bring with anthropocentric conceptions to the biology classroom. 2) How teaching biology concepts using anthropocentric language might help and/or hinder student learning. 3) How faculty may intentionally or unintentionally use anthropocentric language in their own teaching. This research has the potential to contribute to the NSF EHR mission by discovering how specific systems of cognitive understanding may interact with formal classroom teaching to help and/or hinder science learning.

This project will leverage a successful long-term collaboration between cognitive scientists and discipline-based education researchers to investigate the educational consequences of intuitive understandings. These investigators’ previous work revealed systematic relationships between patterns of intuitive, informal thought about biology, including teleological, essentialist, and anthropocentric thinking, as well as revealing misconceptions about biological concepts among students. It showed anthropocentric thinking is more strongly and consistently related to biological misconceptions than other types of intuitive thinking.  However, widespread and frequent use of anthropocentric language by biology faculty in classrooms suggests that at least some instructors see pedagogical merit in such thinking. Moreover, although this project's researchers have found similar anthropocentric thinking and misconceptions among students in two different urban institutions, anthropocentric thinking has been shown to be reduced among people from rural backgrounds. Therefore, this project intends to probe relationships between anthropocentric thinking and biological misconceptions among students from rural backgrounds. It is important to explore in depth the ways in which anthropocentric framing may facilitate learning formal biology concepts (via human examples and analogies) and/or engender misconceptions (via human exceptionalism). Accordingly, the project aims to investigate the effects of anthropocentric framing on biology learning by experimentally presenting biology concepts framed in different ways and assessing resulting learning and misconceptions. Finally, although there is widespread evidence of anthropocentric language in faculty lectures, the degree to which instructors consciously employ such language as a pedagogical strategy is unknown. Therefore, this project seeks to assess faculty metacognitive awareness of their use of anthropocentric language in biology explanations. Results of this research are expected to inform the building of an important and generative theoretical framework integrating disconnected yet theoretically interdependent lines of inquiry in cognitive science and discipline-based science education research. It has the potential to translate this theoretical framework for understanding the acquisition of expertise in life sciences into pedagogical best practices and thus influence the way undergraduate biology is taught. The proposed project is a joint effort between the Conceptual Organization, Reasoning, and Education Laboratory (CORE Lab) at Northeastern University and the Science Education Partnership and Assessment Laboratory (SEPAL) at San Francisco State University, and is supported by the EHR Core Research (ECR) program, which supports work that advances fundamental research on STEM learning and learning environments, broadening participation in STEM, and STEM workforce development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of university-level biology education is to produce experts in the field of biology who are ready to go on to higher degrees in the life sciences or to join the workforce in biotech, medical services, or a host of other vital fields. However, strikingly little is known about how and to what extent biology majors develop this expertise during their undergraduate years. One thing we do know is that students entering the college biology classroom bring with them deeply rooted ways of understanding and thinking about biological phenomena. In other words, during their previous 18-20 years of life, students have developed a sophisticated intuitive biology—a coherent body of explanations about, for example, how and why people get sick, how and why animals show certain patterns of behavior, and how and why plants grow, built up from a combination of practical experience and formal and informal education. Intuitive biology can be contrasted with biological science—the body of knowledge and procedures intentionally conveyed in the life science classroom. The foundation of this research project is the idea that understanding the intuitive conceptual systems we use to reason about biology in informal contexts is critical for understanding the process by which university students learn formal biological science.

One component of intuitive biology is anthropocentric thinking, which involves anchoring understanding of the biological world in human terms. This results in a tendency to see humans as biologically exceptional or to reason about other organisms by analogy to humans. Because our previous NSF-sponsored findings showed that anthropocentric thinking may play an especially complex role in how undergraduates learn biological science, this project focused on the role of anthropocentric thinking in how students learn and understand biology. Below we discuss some important findings and outcomes of the project.

Anthropocentric thinking is widespread in undergraduate students from different backgrounds. We examined how students from urban and rural backgrounds think about biology, because previous research suggested that students growing up in rural areas, with greater opportunity for informal experiences with nature, might be less prone to anthropocentric thinking. However, we found absolutely no differences in anthropocentric thinking between students from urban versus rural settings. We also find similar patterns of anthropocentric thinking among community college students and students at a selective private university. These findings are important because they show that anthropocentric thinking is a widespread phenomenon in university students—if students from very different backgrounds engage in it, it is likely to be a common way of thinking about biology.

Anthropocentric thinking is related to biological misconceptions. Across different academic contexts—urban public universities, rural public universities, private universities, and community colleges—students who used more anthropocentric language in explaining biological concepts were also more likely to agree with biological misconceptions. This shows that anthropocentric thinking is detrimental to learning biological science, and that life science educators should take steps to counteract it.

Framing biological concepts in anthropocentric language is detrimental to student understanding. We presented university students with information about a biological phenomenon with important public health implications: antibiotic resistance. The information was framed in anthropocentric language (portraying antibiotic resistance as a human problem) or neutral language (portraying antibiotic resistance as a biological process). Anthropocentric framing increased students’ use of anthropocentric language to explain antibiotic resistance, which in turn was related to lower accuracy scores and stronger misconceptions. This is important because our previous work shows that biology faculty often use anthropocentric language to frame information they present in class; this suggests that that practice may be counterproductive.

Refutation may be an effective intervention to counteract anthropocentric thinking about biological concepts. “Refutation” involves explaining to students that they may hold a particular misconception or use anthropocentric thinking, explaining why it’s inaccurate, and then providing a scientifically accurate explanation. Our results suggest that refutation approaches can encourage students to introspect about their own ways of understanding, thereby reducing intuitive thinking and misconceptions.

In addition to these substantive findings, the project has supported the engagement of over 100 undergraduate research assistants, six doctoral students, and three postdoctoral fellows in a genuinely interdisciplinary program of research. These trainees are ready to cross traditional disciplinary borders between cognitive psychology, science education, and the life sciences. Indeed, all three postdoctoral fellows supported on the project have subsequently secured university-level teaching posts, where they are positioned to put the results of our research into action to improve science education.

In sum, the proposed project has broadly impacted our theoretical understanding of the acquisition of formal expertise in the life sciences, influenced the current conversation about postsecondary biology education reform and produced researchers with unique training who can continue to cultivate an integrative, interdisciplinary, translational approach to understanding how we teach and learn biology.
